S4.T1.7.caption: Table 1:  Final scores with a segmentation interval  Î´ = 10 â¢ m ğ›¿ 10 m \delta=10~{}\mathrm{m} italic_Î´ = 10 roman_m , a minimal line length  l = 80 â¢ m ğ‘™ 80 m l=80~{}\mathrm{m} italic_l = 80 roman_m , and buffer size  Î² = 6 â¢ m ğ›½ 6 m \beta=6~{}\mathrm{m} italic_Î² = 6 roman_m  for the zonal statistics.
references: The evaluation of our approach resulted in a weighted score of 91.01% for Completeness and 91.64% for Correctness. For Class 2, the most frequent class in the Siegfried Map, we achieved scores of over 94% and 92% using only the pure road geometries and symbolization as training data. Class 5 was the most challenging to classify correctly, probably because the line width of the symbol varies from map sheet to map sheet, due to the inherent quality issues of historical maps. Our implementation based on OpenCV includes a random element for the line widths, the spacing between double line symbols, and the dashing, in order to produce synthetic data with a certain level of variability. Since the Siegfried Map is a hand-made map, all symbolizations are subject to a certain variability, and thus, this random component allows us to further reduce the distribution shift. Detailed evaluations for all road classes are shown in TableÂ 1.

The results in SectionÂ 4 demonstrate that our proposed approach accurately vectorizes and classifies roads in historical maps. We utilize deep learning to extract roads from historical maps (FigureÂ 7), which are then post-processed and vectorized (Figure
Â 8). The resulting vector dataset is used to generate synthetic road class labeled data by leveraging symbol painting (FigureÂ 5). We then employ probabilistic deep learning by training on the synthetic labeled dataset and predicting accurate road class probabilities. Subsequently, we analyze the predicted probabilities along the road segments to identify split points, where the road class changes, allowing accurate road class assignment. Our method has proven to be robust and high-performing based on both visual assessments (FigureÂ 10) and quantitative assessments (TablesÂ 1 and 2), despite the problematic distribution shift between the synthetic data and the original Siegfried Map.

Table 2:  Results of the sensitivity analysis for the hyperparameter of the
split point detection: segmentation interval  Î´ ğ›¿ \delta italic_Î´ , minimum line length  l ğ‘™ l italic_l , and buffer size  Î² ğ›½ \beta italic_Î² . The final results are shown in TableÂ  1  and were calculated with  Î´ = 10 â¢ m ğ›¿ 10 m \delta=10\text{m} italic_Î´ = 10 m ,  l = 80 â¢ m ğ‘™ 80 m l=80\text{m} italic_l = 80 m , and  Î² = 6 â¢ m ğ›½ 6 m \beta=6\text{m} italic_Î² = 6 m
references: The split point detection with the consecutive road class assignment has several hyperparameters that must be selected before applying the framework. These hyperparameters are the discretization or segmentation interval Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ to map the predicted probabilities to the road lines; the minimum line length lğ‘™litalic_l that a section must have between two split points; and the buffer size Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² used in the zonal statistics. To evaluate the robustness of our road class assignment, we conducted a sensitivity analysis. This was achieved by varying specific parameters and assessing the impact on classification performance. The results are presented in TableÂ 2.

The results in SectionÂ 4 demonstrate that our proposed approach accurately vectorizes and classifies roads in historical maps. We utilize deep learning to extract roads from historical maps (FigureÂ 7), which are then post-processed and vectorized (Figure
Â 8). The resulting vector dataset is used to generate synthetic road class labeled data by leveraging symbol painting (FigureÂ 5). We then employ probabilistic deep learning by training on the synthetic labeled dataset and predicting accurate road class probabilities. Subsequently, we analyze the predicted probabilities along the road segments to identify split points, where the road class changes, allowing accurate road class assignment. Our method has proven to be robust and high-performing based on both visual assessments (FigureÂ 10) and quantitative assessments (TablesÂ 1 and 2), despite the problematic distribution shift between the synthetic data and the original Siegfried Map.

references: The Siegfried Map sheets are available as GeoTIFFs with a resolution of 1.25m per pixel in the reference frame CH1903 (EPSG: 21781). TableÂ 3 presents the region and year of each of the map sheets used for training, validation, or testing. Note that geometries are only available for the city of Zurich for the training data; therefore, only parts of the four training sheets were used for training. In order to mask the Siegfried Map sheets without complete ground truth coverage, we downloaded the city boundary from the geoportal of the city of Zurich 444https://www.stadt-zuerich.ch/geodaten/download/95.

references: We utilized the Swiss national map to pretrain our binary segmentation model. Specifically, we used the raster dataset Swiss Map Raster 25 with a resolution of 1.25m per pixel as input data, along with the road geometries from the Swiss Map Vector 25 dataset. Both datasets are georeferenced in the CH1903+ reference frame (EPSG: 2056). An overview of the map sheets can be found in TableÂ 4; FigureÂ 13 shows an example excerpt from the Swiss Map Raster 25 with overlaid roads from the Swiss Map Vector 25 in red.

A2.T5.1.1.table:
Model Pre-trained Accuracy F1 Precision Recall IoU
Attention ResU-Net ImageNet 98.55% 96.63% 96.44% 96.83% 88.84%
A2.T5.1.1.caption: Table 5:  Performance results of the model on the  Swiss Map  validation set during the pre-training phase.
references: As described in the main paper, we experimented with transfer learning by initializing our model with pre-trained weights before training on the Siegfried Map. Initially, we loaded weights pre-trained on ImageNet using PyTorch into the encoder part of our Attention ResU-Net model (Deng etÂ al., 2009), which is based on the ResNet-18 classification model (He etÂ al., 2015). Subsequently, we trained the entire Attention ResU-Net model on the Swiss Map dataset. In this stage, we followed the procedure detailed in AppendixÂ B.2, except that we used a base learning rate of 0.0005 with 3000 warm-up iterations and trained for 20 epochs using 19 Swiss Map sheets. The model was evaluated on a validation set consisting of 5120 patches with a resolution of 500x500 pixels. The scores can be found in TableÂ 5.

Model Augmentation Best epoch Accuracy IoU
Small U-Net No 32/50 97.58% 80.19%
Small U-Net Horizontal/vertical flip (p=0.5), rotation (0°, 90°, 180°, 270°) 47/50 97.76% 82.27%

A2.T8.1.1.caption: Table 8:  The effect of data augmentation on the validation set performance. All models were trained with early stopping based on IoU and a learning rate of 0.1.
references: TableÂ 8 shows the comparison results. Itâ€™s clear that continuous rotation reduces the modelâ€™s generalization ability. This is due to the fact that the coordinate grid lines are consistently horizontal and vertical, leading to a scenario where the model cannot learn to distinguish these lines from roads with similar symbology. On the other hand, discrete rotation enhances performance by preserving the inherent structure of the coordinate grid while artificially increasing the training data size.

Model Pre-trained Accuracy F1 Precision Recall IoU
Small U-Net No 97.76% 94.50% 94.23% 94.78% 82.27%
Attention ResU-Net No 97.78% 94.63% 93.92% 95.37% 82.66%

A2.T9.1.1.caption: Table 9:  Results on validation set for each model using best performing hyperparameters. Best scores are highlighted, final selected model is underlined.
references: The model selection was based on the performance of the validation set. TableÂ 9 presents the results for different models on the validation set. It is clear that our proposed method, Attention ResU-Net, performs better than our baseline, Small U-Net. Furthermore, the results show that initializing the encoder part of Attention ResU-Net with ImageNet pre-trained weights leads to slightly better performance than random initialization. However, the best-performing model was the Attention ResU-Net, which was first initialized with an ImageNet pre-trained encoder before being pre-trained on Swiss Map. Then, the model was fine-tuned on the Siegfried Map. This model was finaly selected for our classification framework.

references: We evaluated all models on the test dataset as an additional study for research purposes without conducting model selection for our framework.
